title: ‘It is the EU against Britain’ French presidential hopeful gets tough on Brexit
text:
‘It is the EU against Britain’ French presidential hopeful gets tough on Brexit ‘It is the EU against Britain’ French presidential hopeful gets tough on Brexit EMMANUEL Macron has declared the EU will unite against Britain as the nation prepares to leave the crumbling bloc. PUBLISHED: 21:28, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 | UPDATED: 21:48, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 EPA Emmanuel Macron said the EU27 would not be divided over Brexit negotiations 
The presidential candidate delivered a stern warning as he addressed 3,000 French voters in Westminster. 
The Europhile, who met with Theresa May earlier today, issued a rallying cry for France to stand alongside the remaining EU member states against Britain. 
He has already called for Britain to “suffer the consequences” of leaving the EU and hours after boldly saying he wants to lure bankers away from London to France on the steps of Downing Street, the threats continued. 
Mr Macron said: "We are at a particular time in the life of Great Britain and all expatriates here, it's pre-Brexit. Related articles Brexit must be a discussion between EU and the UK, it cannot be 27 agendas and the UK Emmanuel Macron 
"We are at a unique time for Europe and for Franco-British relations. 
"What I said to Theresa May is that it (Brexit discussions) would primarily be a European affair. 
"We have an obvious agenda between France and the UK, but for me Brexit must be a discussion between EU and the UK, it cannot be 27 agendas and the UK. 
“If we enter into a debate, or 27 debates, it will be damaging. 
"If we don't negotiate Brexit well, it will be damaging to everyone." 
The 39-year-old who has been leading the opinion polls warned Brexit negotiations will be “long and hard” but maintained France would respect common interests in the long-term. 
Mr Macron said: "We must defend Europe's long-term interests and the special relationship between Britain and France." EPA Mr Macron has already called for Britain to “suffer the consequences” of leaving the EU REUTERS Mr Macron issued a rallying cry for the EU27 to remain united against Britain 
Speaking to a crowd of EU-waving supporters and politicians including Nick Clegg, Mr Macron continued to cosy up to Brussels. 
He said: "We need more Europe and we need a better Europe. 
"We must believe in Europe, love Europe and breathe Europe. I am European so that we can change it together." 
Around 200,000 French voters are believed to be residents in London, making it the sixth-largest centre of population taking part in the presidential election, conducted over two rounds in April and May. AFP GETTY Mr Macron addressed up to 3,000 French voters at Central Hall, Westminster 
Crowds queued around Central Hall to listen to the centrist who is expected to beat the Front National’s Marine Le Pen in the second round on May 7. 
His fighting talk came hours after meetings with Mrs May and the Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond. 
Mr Macron indicated he is ready to allow Britain to keep border controls - and unwanted migrants - on the other side of the Channel after Brexit. 
In talks at Downing Street, the former French economy minister said he was willing to work to "improve" the deal, signed in Le Touquet in 2003. Things you didn't know about Marine Le Pen Mon, February 20, 2017 Marine Le Pen is a French politician who is the president of the National Front, a national-conservative political party in France and one of its main political forces. AFP/Getty Images 1 of 10 Described as more democratic and republican than her nationalist father, she has led a movement of "de-demonization of the Front National" to detoxify it and soften its image 
Mr Macron requested the meeting with Mrs May during a visit to rally support from French ex-pats in London behind his campaign for this spring's election to choose a successor to Mr Hollande. 
Speaking in English, he said he had assured her of his intention to seek a "fair" Brexit, which will "protect and defend French and European interests". 
Downing Street declined to confirm details of the meeting. A spokesman said no other presidential candidates had yet requested a meeting with Mrs May, but added there was a long-standing Government policy not to engage with the Front National. Related articles
